In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, the **pacifist** [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct") involves not actively killing any monster directly. Players must instead attack without killing, use a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") to do the dirty work, or simply run away.

A pacifist player nearly always uses a passive way of killing monsters, such as a pet, or a [ring of conflict](/wiki/Ring_of_conflict "Ring of conflict") for larger groups. [Wands of teleportation](/wiki/Wand_of_teleportation "Wand of teleportation") are used much more often to move a difficult monster somewhere else instead of killing it.

Many players use a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for a "blessed [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of an [Archon](/wiki/Archon "Archon")", giving them a strong enough pet to attack the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor"), as well as being a great help throughout the rest of the game.

## Breaking the conduct

Obviously, if you get experience for the death of a monster, you break the conduct. However, there are a few corner cases where it isn't obvious if you will lose conduct or not.

### Disallowed actions

- You lose conduct if you apply a [drum of earthquake](/wiki/Drum_of_earthquake "Drum of earthquake") or [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging"), and monsters die falling into holes right under them as the [pits](/wiki/Pit "Pit") are created.
- Displacing your pet onto a trap and killing it breaks conduct *only* if the trap was known.
  - The exception is the [boulder trap](/wiki/Boulder_trap "Boulder trap"), which only breaks the conduct if it was *not* known; this is a bug.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)
- Similarly; displacing a pet into water or lava while you are levitating or flying.
- Monsters caught in [stinking clouds](/wiki/Scroll_of_stinking_cloud "Scroll of stinking cloud") get angry at the hero even if he did not create the cloud (which is possible in [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") files). If the bones were left in an old, pre-3.4.1 version, you lose pacifist as well.
- Reflecting [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa")'s gaze if it kills her.
- Causing a system shock on a monster from a failed polymorph. Beware trying to use a wand of polymorph to make a powerful pet.
- Passive attacks are still attacks, and monsters killed from a passive attack while you are polymorphed will still give experience and break the conduct.
- Causing a monster that has engulfed you to be killed by your god's bolt of lightning or disintegration beam breaks the conduct.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)
- "Killing" a monster that is [life saved](/wiki/Amulet_of_life_saving "Amulet of life saving") will still break the conduct. The same applies for monsters that have polymorphed into another form and revert back upon "death". The only exception is a pet that chokes to death on a [leash](/wiki/Leash "Leash"), but is life saved.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

### Allowed actions

- Having a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") kill a monster. This is the main method for killing monsters as a pacifist.
- [Genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").
- Monsters dying from pits you dug (except pits you opened under them by [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a [drum of earthquake](/wiki/Drum_of_earthquake "Drum of earthquake") or [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging")). Peaceful monsters that don't die will be angered, however.
- [Whistling](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle") a pet onto a trap that kills it.
- [Kicking](/wiki/Kick "Kick") a monster on top of a trap, as long as it survives your kick and then dies to the trap.
- In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), having monsters drown in the moat created by the [invocation ritual](/wiki/Invocation_ritual "Invocation ritual") or in pools created by a [fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain").
- Having a monster move into water or lava and die while engulfing you.
- Having a pet or [follower](/wiki/Follower "Follower") vanish because there was no available square on your new dungeon level. (Beware: the game can crash if the follower has a unique item!)
- Killing a monster by reflecting its wand or breath attack.

## Pacifist strategy

The beginning of a *NetHack* game is widely considered to be the hardest phase of the game. On top of that, the pacifist conduct is one of the more difficult conducts in *NetHack*. Hence, pacifist characters are especially sensitive to starting conditions, and any advantages available at the start of the game are of greater importance than usual.

One critical source of initial advantage is your starting choice of [race](/wiki/Race "Race") and [role](/wiki/Role "Role"). The majority of pacifist ascensions on [NAO](/wiki/NAO "NAO") have been accomplished with [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard"), followed by [gnomish](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)") [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer"). This is because Wizards are good for multi-conduct games, and both enjoy several key benefits at the start of the game. For gnomish Healers these include [potion of healing](/wiki/Potion_of_healing "Potion of healing"), spells of [healing](/wiki/Spellbook_of_healing "Spellbook of healing") and [stone to flesh](/wiki/Spellbook_of_stone_to_flesh "Spellbook of stone to flesh"), [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), and the large proportion of [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") monsters in the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines").

The typical course of a pacifist game is as follows. For much of this section, it is assumed that you are a gnomish Healer, although other scenarios are discussed from time to time.

### Starting out

For gnomish Healers, especially aspiring pacifists, the [protection racket](/wiki/Protection_racket "Protection racket") is the best starting strategy. To avoid an early death, you should raise your maximum [hit points](/wiki/Hit_points "Hit points") as soon as possible. The easiest way, if you are a Healer, is to quaff the potions of [healing](/wiki/Potion_of_healing "Potion of healing") and [extra healing](/wiki/Potion_of_extra_healing "Potion of extra healing") in your starting inventory. Before doing this, however, you may want to [pray](/wiki/Pray "Pray") to your god first, since praying can increase your maximum hit points. Praying at [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 1 will not increase your maximum hit points if you already have more than 15 max HP, which is why it is important to pray before quaffing healing potions.

If you do decide to pray first, wait until 100 turns have elapsed, and then throw items upwards [<](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") repeatedly until you are at 5 HP or below. (Don't kick walls if there are sleeping [nymphs](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph") or [zoo](/wiki/Zoo "Zoo") monsters on the level.) Praying under these conditions will maximize the chances of gaining hit points.

It is tempting as a Healer to save the healing potions for emergency use, but this is a mistake. Increasing your hit points is much more useful, and your [healing](/wiki/Spellbook_of_healing "Spellbook of healing") spell is usually adequate in emergencies.

[Nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition") may be a problem for players who are not accustomed to relying on their pets. Since you are dependent on your pet for survival, you will need to spend time luring or herding your pet in the direction that you want to go, and this extra time contributes to hunger. See [Nutrition § Strategy](/wiki/Nutrition#strategy "Nutrition") for some hints on how to stay healthy. In particular, if you are having problems with nutrition, try to save your [prayers](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer") for emergency situations when you are weak or fainting from hunger. Healers start with the [stone to flesh](/wiki/Spellbook_of_stone_to_flesh "Spellbook of stone to flesh") spell and should use this spell as a food source as soon as enough experience levels are gained to cast it (see below).

### Protection racket

As indicated above, most gnomish Healers should make the [protection racket](/wiki/Protection_racket "Protection racket") their first priority. Most of the monsters in the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines") will be peaceful, and with [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") even the darkened mines levels are survivable. A gnomish Healer with 25–30 HP and a medium-sized [dog](/wiki/Dog "Dog") or [cat](/wiki/Cat "Cat") should have no trouble getting to [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown").

Healers start with a large amount of [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold"), often enough that the protection racket can be accomplished without additional gold. However, additional gold is helpful, because even an XL1 character might need up to 3200 gold pieces to buy 9 points of [protection](/wiki/Protection "Protection"). Also, 600 gold pieces will be needed to [gain experience levels](#Leveling_up) at the [Oracle](/wiki/Oracle_\(level\) "Oracle (level)"). The best way to get more gold is by [credit cloning](/wiki/Credit_cloning "Credit cloning") or having your pet steal back expensive items after you sell them.

### Leveling up

After the protection racket, the next goal for a pacifist gnomish Healer is to get to the [Oracle](/wiki/Oracle_\(monster\) "Oracle (monster)") with sufficient gold. By buying a major consultation and a minor consultation (in that order), a level 1 character can reach [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 3. This will allow you to cast [stone to flesh](/wiki/Spellbook_of_stone_to_flesh "Spellbook of stone to flesh") to turn [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") into [huge chunks of meat](/wiki/Huge_chunks_of_meat "Huge chunks of meat"), which represent a plentiful source of food. A level 1 character can even reach experience level 4 by reading a [novel](/wiki/Novel "Novel") before getting the major consultation.

If your starting [power](/wiki/Power "Power") level is less than 5, you may wish to gain a level or two at the Oracle even before performing the [protection racket](/wiki/Protection_racket "Protection racket"), in order to enable healing spells. Each additional level means a longer period of time before you can purchase the last few points of protection; balance this against the benefits of level gain in your situation.

### Mid-game

Eventually, even at XL1, you will reach a point in the dungeon where the random monsters are too strong for domestic pets to handle. Standard strategies such as [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") can help to protect you, but after a while you will still need to upgrade your pet(s) in order to get any further. A little bit of luck is required here, as not every game will provide the resources you need. (Pacifists don't get [death drops](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop").)

If you get a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") early in the game, you should wish for a blessed [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of an [Archon](/wiki/Archon "Archon") (after making sure you can [recharge](/wiki/Charging "Charging") your wand, if the wish is from a [wand of wishing](/wiki/Wand_of_wishing "Wand of wishing")). This will make the rest of the game much easier. One possible [metastrategy](/wiki/Metastrategy "Metastrategy") is to play a large number of characters until one of them gets an early wish—most likely from quaffing at all available [fountains](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain").

Barring an early wish, a [polymorph trap](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap") is a good way to improve your pets. If you hunt for one, the lower mines levels are probably the best (and safest). Each eligible level has a 54% chance of at least one. You need either [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), an [amulet of unchanging](/wiki/Amulet_of_unchanging "Amulet of unchanging"), a [leash](/wiki/Leash "Leash"), or a [magic whistle](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle") in order to polymorph your pets effectively. If you can't find a polymorph trap, try to find a [spellbook of charm monster](/wiki/Spellbook_of_charm_monster "Spellbook of charm monster") or [scroll of taming](/wiki/Scroll_of_taming "Scroll of taming"), which will let you produce new pets. If you encounter [chameleons](/wiki/Chameleon "Chameleon"), you can have your pets eat the corpses in order to (potentially) turn into something better. [Reverse genociding](/wiki/Reverse_genocide "Reverse genocide") chameleons, though possible, is risky and not generally recommended unless nothing else is available. As a last resort, you can smash a [potion of polymorph](/wiki/Potion_of_polymorph "Potion of polymorph") or zap a [wand of polymorph](/wiki/Wand_of_polymorph "Wand of polymorph") on your pet(s), but this has a chance of killing the pet and breaking pacifist conduct. A wand of polymorph is often best saved for [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") rather than used on your pets.

A carefully played pacifist character with a pet Archon or the ability to cast charm monster should find that, aside from the few [specific problems](#Specific_problems_and_solutions) which are listed below, the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") and [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") levels are no harder than they would otherwise be with a regular, non-pacifist character. Whistling your pet into the castle (at the towers) will net you a lot more scrolls and potions than a more direct approach, without any risk to your character. A [leash](/wiki/Leash "Leash") or [magic whistle](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle") are very helpful, and if you make it through the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") without one, consider wishing or polypiling for a magic whistle.

### Ascension run

Pacifist players who have made it to the [Wizard's tower](/wiki/Wizard%27s_tower "Wizard's tower") usually employ one of the following two strategies to deal with the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") and the various monsters in the endgame: either have a well-equipped pet [Archon](/wiki/Archon "Archon") on a [leash](/wiki/Leash "Leash"), or a posse of pet [purple worms](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm") on hand.

The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") starts out as a level 30 monster, and increases by one level each time he reappears. A pet Archon will reach level 28 without help, but after that you will need to give it potions of gain level to raise its level. The Archon will not attack the Wizard unless the Wizard is no more than one level higher than the Archon, so plan accordingly. If your Archon is not already high level (mid 30s), you may want to save up several wishes so that you can wish for potions of gain level if needed. Another possibility is to use a level-draining artifact (such as [the Staff of Aesculapius](/wiki/The_Staff_of_Aesculapius "The Staff of Aesculapius")) to lower the Wizard's level, but take care not to kill the Wizard in the process (check with a [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope "Stethoscope")).

A pet [purple worm](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm") can [instakill](/wiki/Instakill "Instakill") most monsters by eating them, but they will usually never reach high enough level to attack the Wizard of Yendor without conflict. If you rely on purple worms, a [ring of conflict](/wiki/Ring_of_conflict "Ring of conflict") is essential. (Conflict also works with pet Archons, but it is risky until they reach level 25, because the Archons might start attacking you.) Another possibility with a purple worm is to have them chow down on the many [wraiths](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") in the [Valley of the Dead](/wiki/Valley_of_the_Dead "Valley of the Dead"), as a purple worm will gain a level from each wraith, and this level gain will bypass their normal maximum. However, pet worms usually don't last very long—they are extremely vulnerable to shapeshifters, green slime, huge monsters, and players annoyed of waiting for them to eat.

A high-level pet Archon with reflection and good weapons and armor (e.g. +7 [Frost Brand](/wiki/Frost_Brand "Frost Brand"), [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") −25) will quickly kill pretty much every monster you encounter, even in the endgame, except for [footrices](/wiki/Footrice "Footrice") and monsters with [digestion](/wiki/Digestion "Digestion") attacks. Using a [leash](/wiki/Leash "Leash") or two is highly recommended, especially in the [Elemental Planes](/wiki/Elemental_Planes "Elemental Planes"), since otherwise you will be in bad shape if you enter one of the portals without your pets.

## Specific problems and solutions

### Team gecko

Weak monsters such as [geckos](/wiki/Gecko "Gecko") can die if you accidentally hit them. This causes you to lose pacifist conduct and represents a major threat to any would-be pacifist. Players should prepare themselves for a lot of frustration. At the start of the game, there is nothing you can do except play very carefully, using movement commands which do not attack, such as [m](/wiki/M "M"), [g](/wiki/G "G"), capital vi movement keys, and [\_](/wiki/Underscore "Underscore"). Once you get a [cream pie](/wiki/Cream_pie "Cream pie"), you can [wield](/wiki/Wield "Wield") it. A character wielding a cream pie does no damage upon hitting a monster, regardless of any damage bonuses you may have. However, if you hit anything, the cream pie will splat. Feel free to wield a whole stack - only one will splat at a time.

If you have a pet that can kill [Keystone Kops](/wiki/Keystone_Kop_\(monster_class\) "Keystone Kop (monster class)"), you can find a suitable [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and steal a [gold piece](/wiki/Gold_piece "Gold piece") several times to build up a stockpile of [cream pies](/wiki/Cream_pie "Cream pie"). Dig a pit in front of the shop door to keep the [shopkeeper](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") inside - if they approach you after you rob the shop, you can [pay](/wiki/Pay "Pay") the shopkeeper to appease them.

If you don't have a cream pie, wielding a very weak weapon (a [Puddingbane](/wiki/Puddingbane "Puddingbane")) will make sure the damage is limited to 1 even if you have a damage bonus from a [ring of increase damage](/wiki/Ring_of_increase_damage "Ring of increase damage") or from [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") - however, even a single point of accidental damage can still kill weakened monsters. To avoid strength bonuses, do not use a non-weapon object unless your strength is 15 or lower.

More drastic solutions include [genociding](/wiki/Genociding "Genociding") bump-kill candidates (if you have excess scrolls), or [remapping the movement keys](/wiki/Pacifist/screen "Pacifist/screen") to safe alternatives.

### Weapon considerations

On rare occasions, it is helpful for a pacifist to use weapons to attack monsters. If you have a [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope "Stethoscope"), you can selectively reduce monsters to very few hit points or even one hit point using a weak weapon or non-weapon such as a [Puddingbane](/wiki/Puddingbane "Puddingbane"). This helps your pet kill [floating eyes](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye") if you have a [blindfold](/wiki/Blindfold "Blindfold"). Later, once you get a [level-draining](/wiki/Drain_life "Drain life") artifact, you can use it to drain high level monsters to the point where your pet will attack it.

### Gaining experience

Here is a full list of pacifist methods for gaining experience:

- Quaffing [potions of gain level](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_level "Potion of gain level")
- Eating [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") corpses
- Lying with [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi")
- Talking with the Oracle
- Eating [tripe rations](/wiki/Tripe_ration "Tripe ration")
- Quaffing from [sinks](/wiki/Sink "Sink")
- Untrapping [squeaky boards](/wiki/Squeaky_board "Squeaky board")
- Reading a [novel](/wiki/Novel "Novel") (first time only)
- [Polymorphing](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into your own [race](/wiki/Race "Race") (but equally likely to lose a level)

[Potions of gain level](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_level "Potion of gain level") are usually best saved for a pet Archon. [Chatting](/wiki/Chat "Chat") with the Oracle is useful in the early game, but only works once per game. This leaves eating [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") corpses and consorting with [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi") as the primary level-up methods for a pacifist. Wraiths can be [reverse genocided](/wiki/Reverse_genocide "Reverse genocide") or lured from a [graveyard](/wiki/Graveyard "Graveyard") level such as the [Valley of the Dead](/wiki/Valley_of_the_Dead "Valley of the Dead") (use [level teleport](/wiki/Level_teleport "Level teleport") for maximum speed, or [charm monster](/wiki/Charm_monster "Charm monster")). Tripe rations are a handy way to regain levels lost to [level drain](/wiki/Level_drain "Level drain").

If you run across any wraith corpses in the dungeon, you should eat them, as it will make it easier to enter the [Quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") later on. However, unless there is some need to gain levels (for example, to cast [charm monster](/wiki/Spellbook_of_charm_monster "Spellbook of charm monster")), you should not bother actively gaining experience until necessary for the [Quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest"), in order to keep the difficulty of random monsters low.

Most of the time, gaining levels is not a big challenge compared with all of the other difficulties of pacifism, and in general if you are opportunistic with [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") corpses and [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi") summoning via [sinks](/wiki/Sink "Sink") you should have no trouble. However, if your game is lacking in sinks and wraiths, you may have to take matters into your own hands. Perhaps the easiest solution is to [polypile](/wiki/Polypile "Polypile") or [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for a [magic marker](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker") and [reverse genocide](/wiki/Reverse_genocide "Reverse genocide") wraiths. Other methods include letting [water demons](/wiki/Water_demon "Water demon") hit you to summon [foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi"), [farming](/wiki/Farming#Throne_farming "Farming") for potions to [alchemize](/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy") by repeatedly #looting a throne (note changes between versions in this), or [wraith farming](/wiki/Farming#Wraith_farming "Farming") with the [Book of the Dead](/wiki/Book_of_the_Dead "Book of the Dead").

### Gaining alignment

In order to fully take advantage of what your god can do for you (fix problems) you'll need to have an [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") greater than zero. If your role starts the game with zero alignment record, it should be raised before you run into your first major trouble. Also, it must be 20 for you to be allowed on the [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest").

With [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer") or [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") characters, your alignment can be easily raised by healing your pets; you get one alignment point each time you heal them.

[Chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic") characters gain one point of alignment each time they sleep with a [foocubus](/wiki/Foocubus "Foocubus"), which is also a good way to gain experience.

With [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") characters, it is a bit more difficult. The easiest technique to get the first couple of points of alignment is to pray after the 300th turn with a [minor trouble](/wiki/Minor_trouble "Minor trouble"), since your initial [prayer timeout](/wiki/Prayer_timeout "Prayer timeout") is set to 300. This will only work for the first two points of alignment.

After that, you can get more alignment by giving gold to [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest"). Giving a priest of your alignment (hope for a co-aligned Minetown altar) 600 times your level in gold will raise your alignment two points, but only if you don't have more than 2 times that amount of gold in your inventory at the time. So stash away all the gold you're not giving to the priest in a bag, then give to charity!

You can get a slightly better deal once you've bought the first 9 points of protection from that co-aligned priest. After that, if you spend 400 times your level in gold, you have only a small chance of getting more protection; you will usually get the alignment bonus instead (assuming the amount is more than half your current gold).

[Sacrificing unicorns](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn") of other alignments is probably the next-easiest way to raise your alignment as a neutral character.

Neutral atheist non-Healer pacifists have an especially hard time raising their alignment. The only method available to them is to anger a cross-aligned priest. Ben Hiles has ascended an [atheist pacifist Gnomish Wizard](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/browse_thread/thread/9aaa937386570454/59400e18fbd6250a?lnk=st\&q=\&rnum=1#59400e18fbd6250a) this way.

In [3.4.3](/wiki/3.4.3 "3.4.3") and earlier, a [helm of opposite alignment](/wiki/Helm_of_opposite_alignment "Helm of opposite alignment") could be used to open up other deities' methods of gaining alignment, such as casting healing spells on pets; unfortunately, as of [3.6.0](/wiki/3.6.0 "3.6.0"), putting on or removing the helm resets your alignment to zero, making the practice pointless.

### Engulfing monsters

- *Main article: [Engulfing](/wiki/Engulfing "Engulfing")*

If a monster [engulfs](/wiki/Engulfing "Engulfing") you, [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a [tooled horn](/wiki/Tooled_horn "Tooled horn") will cause the monster to expel you. Pacifists should thus make it a priority to find a tooled horn. Other escape methods such as [teleportation](/wiki/Teleportation "Teleportation"), [ring of slow digestion](/wiki/Ring_of_slow_digestion "Ring of slow digestion"), [wand of slow monster](/wiki/Wand_of_slow_monster "Wand of slow monster"), [wand of opening](/wiki/Wand_of_opening "Wand of opening"), [cloak of displacement](/wiki/Cloak_of_displacement "Cloak of displacement"), [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging"), and the [knock](/wiki/Spellbook_of_knock "Spellbook of knock") and [slow monster](/wiki/Spellbook_of_slow_monster "Spellbook of slow monster") spells can also be used in various situations. An engulfer without a digestion attack will eventually spit you out if you survive.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

[Air elementals](/wiki/Air_elemental "Air elemental") are dangerous opponents, since they are fast and often re-engulf you immediately after you escape. On a no-teleport level, zapping the air elemental with a wand of teleportation will move it out of your way. On levels that permit teleportation, you must zap yourself and not the air elemental in order to teleport outside of the monster.

Pets cannot be engulfed except by monsters with [digestion](/wiki/Digestion "Digestion") attacks; however, a pet which is engulfed by a digestion attack suffers [instadeath](/wiki/Instadeath "Instadeath"). Fortunately, the only monsters with digestion attacks are [trappers](/wiki/Trapper "Trapper"), [lurkers above](/wiki/Lurkers_above "Lurkers above"), and [purple worms](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm"). All three of them move slowly if at all, so they are easy to avoid if you have [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") or (to a lesser extent) [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning"). Another option, if you don't intend to have any pet [purple worms](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm"), is to [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide") them.

### Cockatrices

Most pets will not attack cockatrices. If you are unable to obtain a stoning-resistant pet such as a [yellow dragon](/wiki/Yellow_dragon "Yellow dragon") or a [gargoyle](/wiki/Gargoyle "Gargoyle"), cockatrices will be very annoying obstacles. Taming, teleportation, genocide, conflict, and luring a wounded cockatrice into a pit are about the only ways to get rid of them without a pet that is willing to attack them. The easiest solution is to simply genocide them. In a normal game, genociding cockatrices is usually not a good idea, as their corpses are immensely useful against certain difficult enemies. This is not true in a pacifist game, as your pets will not wield cockatrice corpses if they have an artifact or no gloves, and the conduct keeps you from using it yourself. Additionally, any cockatrice corpses left on the ground could potentially be wielded against you by a [soldier](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") wearing gloves. The only potential uses for cockatrices in a pacifist game are with conflict, and deliberately stoning a weak pet [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem") to get a stronger stone golem.

### High level monsters

A [ring of conflict](/wiki/Ring_of_conflict "Ring of conflict") will cause your pets to attack other monsters (and you) regardless of any differences in monster level. If you don't have conflict, you will have to spend some effort to raise your pets' levels, since without conflict a pet will not attack monsters more than one level higher than it. Another option is to turn the monster into a [green slime](/wiki/Green_slime "Green slime") and either have a pet kill it or simply run away. It is possible to slime the Wizard of Yendor and polymorph into a nymph to steal the Book of the Dead. This has the added advantage of the Wizard not reappearing until after performing the invocation ritual.

A pet [Archon](/wiki/Archon "Archon") will reach level 28 without any special effort. After that, the only way to raise its level is to give it [potions of gain level](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_level "Potion of gain level"). Of the monsters normally encountered in the game, only [Asmodeus](/wiki/Asmodeus "Asmodeus"), [Baalzebub](/wiki/Baalzebub "Baalzebub"), [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus"), the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor"), and the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") are above level 29. It is usually best to bribe [Asmodeus](/wiki/Asmodeus "Asmodeus") and [Baalzebub](/wiki/Baalzebub "Baalzebub"), since otherwise they are fairly hard to kill. Asmodeus, in particular, is level 49, which is very difficult to handle without conflict. [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus") is level 30 and thus requires a level 29 Archon to kill—give your Archon one potion of gain level. The [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") have a base level of 30, but their actual level will be between 33 and 37, depending on your level and the depth of the Sanctum.

The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") starts at level 30, but each death of the Wizard or his [clones](/wiki/Double_trouble "Double trouble") increases the level of his next appearance by one.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) For this reason, it is a good idea to ensure that your Archon is several experience levels higher than the Wizard before beginning the ascension run, or have a level draining artifact on hand to use against him (check his level and hit points periodically with a stethoscope to make sure you don't kill him). As usual, if the level draining artifact is your [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"), be prepared as it will eventually be stolen by the Wizard if left out long enough. The most convenient source of [potions of gain level](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_level "Potion of gain level") is probably #looting the [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") in [Vlad's Tower](/wiki/Vlad%27s_Tower "Vlad's Tower") repeatedly—about 2–4% of all monsters generated will carry such a potion.

Another option is to tame [liches](/wiki/Lich "Lich") and grow them into arch-liches; a fully leveled arch-lich is level 37, sufficient to attack the Wizard for several incarnations. Arch-liches have the additional advantage of being covetous; once wounded both the Wizard and the tame lich will teleport to the upstairs (if it exists) and will continue to fight. Monsters will not escape upstairs or cast healing spells if you are not nearby, so the two will continue to fight until one of them dies—typically the Wizard, as an arch-lich has more damaging attacks. An arch-lich specifically wants the Book of the Dead and will therefore pick it up after the Wizard dies, but it may be difficult to get the Book back; the lich will still drop carried items due to being tame, but tends to immediately pick the Book up again.

Without a large supply of potions of gain level, it is always possible that the Wizard will reach a point where a pet Archon will refuse to attack him without conflict. The easiest way to get a level 49 pet is to tame a purple worm and [farm for wraiths](/wiki/Farming#wraith_farming "Farming") with the cursed Book of the Dead. Purple worms will gain a level whenever they swallow a wraith, ignoring corpse dropping odds. Beware the by-product arch-liches, and that the Wizard will haunt you unless you steal the book without killing him. Once at level 49, the pet worm will always be able to quickly kill the Wizard and will have enough HP to survive most combat. You still need to keep it away from disintegration blasts, polymorph traps, shapeshifters, and the Riders.

### Traps

Certain traps are dangerous for pacifists. A [polymorph trap](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap") can turn a strong pet into a weak pet. [Level teleporters](/wiki/Level_teleporter "Level teleporter") and [trap doors](/wiki/Trap_door "Trap door") can separate you from your pet. If you have a [trap detection](/wiki/Trap#Strategy "Trap") method, it might be a good idea to search each level for dangerous traps and disable them, or keep your pets away. In most cases, it is enough to put a cursed object or a boulder on the trap, or to dig a [pit](/wiki/Pit "Pit").

In the main dungeon, most traps can be avoided by walking in corridors instead of rooms. [Digging](/wiki/Digging "Digging") your own corridors is a relatively safe method of travel, but tedious and usually not necessary. In [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), try to stay in front of your pet at all times by using the layout of the maze to block your pet from walking in front of you. This will ensure that you encounter dangerous traps before your pet steps into them; once you find a dangerous trap, you should disable it immediately. Be aware, however, that when dangerous monsters are in the vicinity, you will want to keep your pet in front of you instead, so switch between the two modes of exploration as appropriate. [Extrinsic telepathy](/wiki/Extrinsic_telepathy "Extrinsic telepathy") is extremely valuable here, as is [magic mapping](/wiki/Magic_mapping "Magic mapping").

Because you could lose your pet at any time to a trap, it is important for a pacifist to have at least two pets (if not more). A diversity of pets can handle a diversity of challenges.

### Water and lava

Most pets, except for flying pets and a few that can survive under water, will die if you displace them into [water](/wiki/Moat "Moat") or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"). If they die in this way, you will lose pacifist conduct. Be especially careful with pets on levels with water or lava. If you are not able to play with the necessary amount of caution, one alternative is to make sure all your pets can fly (and abandon the ones that can't).

In 3.6, if you drown a monster by creating a [pool](/wiki/Pool "Pool") under it, either by digging a [fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain") or by doing the [invocation](/wiki/Invocation "Invocation"), it breaks the conduct, so it is desirable to check for nearby monsters.

### Monsters with special abilities

Many special abilities, such as [mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer")' brain-sucking attack and [touch of death](/wiki/Touch_of_death "Touch of death"), won't work on your pet. Major exceptions include a [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice")'s stoning attack or a [black dragon](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon")'s breath attack, which can kill your pet instantly. Pets will not attack a footrice unless they are stoning resistant or you are causing [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict"). The way to deal with cockatrices is to have a stoning resistant pet, [teleport](/wiki/Teleport "Teleport") them, [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") them, [cancel](/wiki/Cancel "Cancel") them, or use [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"). Stoned pets may be recovered by the [stone to flesh](/wiki/Spellbook_of_stone_to_flesh "Spellbook of stone to flesh") spell.

[Black dragons](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon") are best handled by giving your pets [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection"), or using [cancellation](/wiki/Cancellation "Cancellation") or [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

A [floating eye](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye")'s gaze attack will affect pets. Keep any pets without [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") away from floating eyes until you obtain an [expensive camera](/wiki/Expensive_camera "Expensive camera"), [wand of make invisible](/wiki/Wand_of_make_invisible "Wand of make invisible"), or some other means of neutralizing their gaze attack. You can wake pets up with a [leather drum](/wiki/Leather_drum "Leather drum"), a [tooled horn](/wiki/Tooled_horn "Tooled horn"), or a depleted [drum of earthquake](/wiki/Drum_of_earthquake "Drum of earthquake") or magical horn.

[Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa") is another special case. If you [reflect](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") Medusa's gaze, you will lose pacifist conduct, so don't do that. Standard techniques for dispatching Medusa include using a pet with reflection, [cancelling](/wiki/Cancel "Cancel") or blinding Medusa, or blindfolding yourself and dropping a [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death") in her path for her to use.

### Wishing

Before [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact"), make sure that you can survive its [artifact blast](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast"). Good artifact wishes for a pacifist include the following:

- [The Eye of the Aethiopica](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Aethiopica "The Eye of the Aethiopica")

  - Allows you to cast healing spells more frequently, if you are a Healer.
  - [Telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") helps you avoid hitting monsters.
  - [Magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") is very helpful when polymorphing pets in polymorph traps.
  - [Branchporting](/wiki/Branchport "Branchport") is useful for [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") luring.

- [The Orb of Fate](/wiki/The_Orb_of_Fate "The Orb of Fate")

  - Confers half damage, which helps you survive.
  - The [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball") function lets you look for dangerous traps. Recharge using [the Platinum Yendorian Express Card](/wiki/The_Platinum_Yendorian_Express_Card "The Platinum Yendorian Express Card") for even greater effect.
  - Level teleport is handy for [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") luring.

- [The Platinum Yendorian Express Card](/wiki/The_Platinum_Yendorian_Express_Card "The Platinum Yendorian Express Card")

  - Pacifists rely on [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") more than usual, especially wands of [fire](/wiki/Wand_of_fire "Wand of fire") and [lightning](/wiki/Wand_of_lightning "Wand of lightning"), which can engrave [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth"), and [wands of teleportation](/wiki/Wand_of_teleportation "Wand of teleportation"), which can move monsters out of the way. Being able to recharge wands is good.
  - Also confers telepathy and magic resistance.
  - Allows unlimited use of the Orb of Fate to search for traps. (A regular [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball") will also work, but unless your [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") is at least 20, a regular crystal ball has a chance of exploding when used.)

- If you're not a Healer, a [level draining](/wiki/Level_drain "Level drain") artifact may be worth a wish.

Useful non-artifact wishes include the usual [ascension kit](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit") equipment, plus any of the following depending on your situation:

- blessed figurine of an Archon
- blessed spellbook of charm monster
- blessed magic whistle
- blessed ring of conflict

### No death drops

Pacifists get less loot, and what they do get is much less useful. Random items are generated only during initial level generation or as [death drops](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop") which break the conduct. Monsters are created only with a very narrow [selection of items](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory"). [Polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling"), [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish"), [writing books and scrolls](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker"), divine gifts, and [alchemy](/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy") offer a way out, but all of these (except alchemy) break other [conducts](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct"). On the flip side, you can identify items by that monsters were created with them, particularly when this varies by monster.

## Pacifist ascensions

Pacifist [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer") and [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") are common, but a few other classes have been ascended as pacifists:

- [A pacifist Archeologist](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/2f82d79910f8d914) by [Marvin](/wiki/Marvin "Marvin")
- [A pacifist Rogue](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/d407fabb048f84e4) by Marvin
- [A pacifist Monk](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/f5a3e2ac50847dfa) (and 8 other conducts too) by Brad Sagarin

No [YAPAPs](/wiki/YAPAP "YAPAP") have been posted to [RGRN](/wiki/RGRN "RGRN") for a Barbarian, Caveman, Knight, Ranger, Priest, Samurai, Tourist, or Valkyrie.

On [NAO](/wiki/NAO "NAO"), there have been 14 Healer, 12 Wizard, 3 Monk, 2 Tourist, and 1 each of Archaeologist, Barbarian, Caveman, Rogue, Priest, Knight, and Valkyrie ascensions.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7).

Pacifism is the most difficult conduct; only 0.8% of all winning NAO accounts have a pacifist ascension.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

## Variants

All variants track Pacifist normally, but some have changes that make the conduct less frustrating and error-prone:

### FIQHack

[Weapon-tools](/wiki/Weapon-tool "Weapon-tool") always display "You begin bashing" when attacking unskilled with the tool; this helps the player realize their mistake if they accidentally attack with a pickaxe and it doesn't kill the monster.

### XNetHack

If the player has not attacked any monsters after 100 turns have passed, they are prompted to confirm any melee attack. Once they confirm an attack, or kill a monster, the prompt no longer appears.

Pacifist

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

In NetHack, the pacifist conduct involves not actively killing any monster directly. Players must instead attack without killing, use a pet to do the dirty work, or simply run away.

A pacifist player nearly always uses a passive way of killing monsters, such as a pet, or a ring of conflict for larger groups. Wands of teleportation are used much more often to move a difficult monster somewhere else instead of killing it.

Many players use a wish for a "blessed figurine of an Archon", giving them a strong enough pet to attack the Wizard of Yendor, as well as being a great help throughout the rest of the game.

Breaking the conduct

Obviously, if you get experience for the death of a monster, you break the conduct. However, there are a few corner cases where it isn't obvious if you will lose conduct or not.

Disallowed actions

  • You lose conduct if you apply a drum of earthquake or wand of digging, and monsters die falling into holes right under them as the pits are created.
  • Displacing your pet onto a trap and killing it breaks conduct only if the trap was known.
    • The exception is the boulder trap, which only breaks the conduct if it was not known; this is a bug.[1]
  • Similarly; displacing a pet into water or lava while you are levitating or flying.
  • Monsters caught in stinking clouds get angry at the hero even if he did not create the cloud (which is possible in bones files). If the bones were left in an old, pre-3.4.1 version, you lose pacifist as well.
  • Reflecting Medusa's gaze if it kills her.
  • Causing a system shock on a monster from a failed polymorph. Beware trying to use a wand of polymorph to make a powerful pet.
  • Passive attacks are still attacks, and monsters killed from a passive attack while you are polymorphed will still give experience and break the conduct.
  • Causing a monster that has engulfed you to be killed by your god's bolt of lightning or disintegration beam breaks the conduct.[2]
  • "Killing" a monster that is life saved will still break the conduct. The same applies for monsters that have polymorphed into another form and revert back upon "death". The only exception is a pet that chokes to death on a leash, but is life saved.[3]

Allowed actions

  • Having a pet kill a monster. This is the main method for killing monsters as a pacifist.
  • Genocide.
  • Monsters dying from pits you dug (except pits you opened under them by applying a drum of earthquake or wand of digging). Peaceful monsters that don't die will be angered, however.
  • Whistling a pet onto a trap that kills it.
  • Kicking a monster on top of a trap, as long as it survives your kick and then dies to the trap.
  • In NetHack 3.4.3, having monsters drown in the moat created by the invocation ritual or in pools created by a fountain.
  • Having a monster move into water or lava and die while engulfing you.
  • Having a pet or follower vanish because there was no available square on your new dungeon level. (Beware: the game can crash if the follower has a unique item!)
  • Killing a monster by reflecting its wand or breath attack.

Pacifist strategy

The beginning of a NetHack game is widely considered to be the hardest phase of the game. On top of that, the pacifist conduct is one of the more difficult conducts in NetHack. Hence, pacifist characters are especially sensitive to starting conditions, and any advantages available at the start of the game are of greater importance than usual.

One critical source of initial advantage is your starting choice of race and role. The majority of pacifist ascensions on NAO have been accomplished with Wizards, followed by gnomish Healers. This is because Wizards are good for multi-conduct games, and both enjoy several key benefits at the start of the game. For gnomish Healers these include potion of healing, spells of healing and stone to flesh, infravision, and the large proportion of peaceful monsters in the Gnomish Mines.

The typical course of a pacifist game is as follows. For much of this section, it is assumed that you are a gnomish Healer, although other scenarios are discussed from time to time.

Starting out

For gnomish Healers, especially aspiring pacifists, the protection racket is the best starting strategy. To avoid an early death, you should raise your maximum hit points as soon as possible. The easiest way, if you are a Healer, is to quaff the potions of healing and extra healing in your starting inventory. Before doing this, however, you may want to pray to your god first, since praying can increase your maximum hit points. Praying at experience level 1 will not increase your maximum hit points if you already have more than 15 max HP, which is why it is important to pray before quaffing healing potions.

If you do decide to pray first, wait until 100 turns have elapsed, and then throw items upwards < repeatedly until you are at 5 HP or below. (Don't kick walls if there are sleeping nymphs or zoo monsters on the level.) Praying under these conditions will maximize the chances of gaining hit points.

It is tempting as a Healer to save the healing potions for emergency use, but this is a mistake. Increasing your hit points is much more useful, and your healing spell is usually adequate in emergencies.

Nutrition may be a problem for players who are not accustomed to relying on their pets. Since you are dependent on your pet for survival, you will need to spend time luring or herding your pet in the direction that you want to go, and this extra time contributes to hunger. See Nutrition § Strategy for some hints on how to stay healthy. In particular, if you are having problems with nutrition, try to save your prayers for emergency situations when you are weak or fainting from hunger. Healers start with the stone to flesh spell and should use this spell as a food source as soon as enough experience levels are gained to cast it (see below).

Protection racket

As indicated above, most gnomish Healers should make the protection racket their first priority. Most of the monsters in the Gnomish Mines will be peaceful, and with infravision even the darkened mines levels are survivable. A gnomish Healer with 25–30 HP and a medium-sized dog or cat should have no trouble getting to Minetown.

Healers start with a large amount of gold, often enough that the protection racket can be accomplished without additional gold. However, additional gold is helpful, because even an XL1 character might need up to 3200 gold pieces to buy 9 points of protection. Also, 600 gold pieces will be needed to gain experience levels at the Oracle. The best way to get more gold is by credit cloning or having your pet steal back expensive items after you sell them.

Leveling up

After the protection racket, the next goal for a pacifist gnomish Healer is to get to the Oracle with sufficient gold. By buying a major consultation and a minor consultation (in that order), a level 1 character can reach experience level 3. This will allow you to cast stone to flesh to turn boulders into huge chunks of meat, which represent a plentiful source of food. A level 1 character can even reach experience level 4 by reading a novel before getting the major consultation.

If your starting power level is less than 5, you may wish to gain a level or two at the Oracle even before performing the protection racket, in order to enable healing spells. Each additional level means a longer period of time before you can purchase the last few points of protection; balance this against the benefits of level gain in your situation.

Mid-game

Eventually, even at XL1, you will reach a point in the dungeon where the random monsters are too strong for domestic pets to handle. Standard strategies such as Elbereth can help to protect you, but after a while you will still need to upgrade your pet(s) in order to get any further. A little bit of luck is required here, as not every game will provide the resources you need. (Pacifists don't get death drops.)

If you get a wish early in the game, you should wish for a blessed figurine of an Archon (after making sure you can recharge your wand, if the wish is from a wand of wishing). This will make the rest of the game much easier. One possible metastrategy is to play a large number of characters until one of them gets an early wish—most likely from quaffing at all available fountains.

Barring an early wish, a polymorph trap is a good way to improve your pets. If you hunt for one, the lower mines levels are probably the best (and safest). Each eligible level has a 54% chance of at least one. You need either magic resistance, an amulet of unchanging, a leash, or a magic whistle in order to polymorph your pets effectively. If you can't find a polymorph trap, try to find a spellbook of charm monster or scroll of taming, which will let you produce new pets. If you encounter chameleons, you can have your pets eat the corpses in order to (potentially) turn into something better. Reverse genociding chameleons, though possible, is risky and not generally recommended unless nothing else is available. As a last resort, you can smash a potion of polymorph or zap a wand of polymorph on your pet(s), but this has a chance of killing the pet and breaking pacifist conduct. A wand of polymorph is often best saved for polypiling rather than used on your pets.

A carefully played pacifist character with a pet Archon or the ability to cast charm monster should find that, aside from the few specific problems which are listed below, the Castle and Gehennom levels are no harder than they would otherwise be with a regular, non-pacifist character. Whistling your pet into the castle (at the towers) will net you a lot more scrolls and potions than a more direct approach, without any risk to your character. A leash or magic whistle are very helpful, and if you make it through the Castle without one, consider wishing or polypiling for a magic whistle.

Ascension run

Pacifist players who have made it to the Wizard's tower usually employ one of the following two strategies to deal with the Wizard of Yendor and the various monsters in the endgame: either have a well-equipped pet Archon on a leash, or a posse of pet purple worms on hand.

The Wizard of Yendor starts out as a level 30 monster, and increases by one level each time he reappears. A pet Archon will reach level 28 without help, but after that you will need to give it potions of gain level to raise its level. The Archon will not attack the Wizard unless the Wizard is no more than one level higher than the Archon, so plan accordingly. If your Archon is not already high level (mid 30s), you may want to save up several wishes so that you can wish for potions of gain level if needed. Another possibility is to use a level-draining artifact (such as the Staff of Aesculapius) to lower the Wizard's level, but take care not to kill the Wizard in the process (check with a stethoscope).

A pet purple worm can instakill most monsters by eating them, but they will usually never reach high enough level to attack the Wizard of Yendor without conflict. If you rely on purple worms, a ring of conflict is essential. (Conflict also works with pet Archons, but it is risky until they reach level 25, because the Archons might start attacking you.) Another possibility with a purple worm is to have them chow down on the many wraiths in the Valley of the Dead, as a purple worm will gain a level from each wraith, and this level gain will bypass their normal maximum. However, pet worms usually don't last very long—they are extremely vulnerable to shapeshifters, green slime, huge monsters, and players annoyed of waiting for them to eat.

A high-level pet Archon with reflection and good weapons and armor (e.g. +7 Frost Brand, AC −25) will quickly kill pretty much every monster you encounter, even in the endgame, except for footrices and monsters with digestion attacks. Using a leash or two is highly recommended, especially in the Elemental Planes, since otherwise you will be in bad shape if you enter one of the portals without your pets.

Specific problems and solutions

Team gecko

Weak monsters such as geckos can die if you accidentally hit them. This causes you to lose pacifist conduct and represents a major threat to any would-be pacifist. Players should prepare themselves for a lot of frustration. At the start of the game, there is nothing you can do except play very carefully, using movement commands which do not attack, such as m, g, capital vi movement keys, and _. Once you get a cream pie, you can wield it. A character wielding a cream pie does no damage upon hitting a monster, regardless of any damage bonuses you may have. However, if you hit anything, the cream pie will splat. Feel free to wield a whole stack - only one will splat at a time.

If you have a pet that can kill Keystone Kops, you can find a suitable shop and steal a gold piece several times to build up a stockpile of cream pies. Dig a pit in front of the shop door to keep the shopkeeper inside - if they approach you after you rob the shop, you can pay the shopkeeper to appease them.

If you don't have a cream pie, wielding a very weak weapon (a Puddingbane) will make sure the damage is limited to 1 even if you have a damage bonus from a ring of increase damage or from strength - however, even a single point of accidental damage can still kill weakened monsters. To avoid strength bonuses, do not use a non-weapon object unless your strength is 15 or lower.

More drastic solutions include genociding bump-kill candidates (if you have excess scrolls), or remapping the movement keys to safe alternatives.

Weapon considerations

On rare occasions, it is helpful for a pacifist to use weapons to attack monsters. If you have a stethoscope, you can selectively reduce monsters to very few hit points or even one hit point using a weak weapon or non-weapon such as a Puddingbane. This helps your pet kill floating eyes if you have a blindfold. Later, once you get a level-draining artifact, you can use it to drain high level monsters to the point where your pet will attack it.

Gaining experience

Here is a full list of pacifist methods for gaining experience:

  • Quaffing potions of gain level
  • Eating wraith corpses
  • Lying with foocubi
  • Talking with the Oracle
  • Eating tripe rations
  • Quaffing from sinks
  • Untrapping squeaky boards
  • Reading a novel (first time only)
  • Polymorphing into your own race (but equally likely to lose a level)

Potions of gain level are usually best saved for a pet Archon. Chatting with the Oracle is useful in the early game, but only works once per game. This leaves eating wraith corpses and consorting with foocubi as the primary level-up methods for a pacifist. Wraiths can be reverse genocided or lured from a graveyard level such as the Valley of the Dead (use level teleport for maximum speed, or charm monster). Tripe rations are a handy way to regain levels lost to level drain.

If you run across any wraith corpses in the dungeon, you should eat them, as it will make it easier to enter the Quest later on. However, unless there is some need to gain levels (for example, to cast charm monster), you should not bother actively gaining experience until necessary for the Quest, in order to keep the difficulty of random monsters low.

Most of the time, gaining levels is not a big challenge compared with all of the other difficulties of pacifism, and in general if you are opportunistic with wraith corpses and foocubi summoning via sinks you should have no trouble. However, if your game is lacking in sinks and wraiths, you may have to take matters into your own hands. Perhaps the easiest solution is to polypile or wish for a magic marker and reverse genocide wraiths. Other methods include letting water demons hit you to summon foocubi, farming for potions to alchemize by repeatedly #looting a throne (note changes between versions in this), or wraith farming with the Book of the Dead.

Gaining alignment

In order to fully take advantage of what your god can do for you (fix problems) you'll need to have an alignment record greater than zero. If your role starts the game with zero alignment record, it should be raised before you run into your first major trouble. Also, it must be 20 for you to be allowed on the quest.

With Healers or lawful characters, your alignment can be easily raised by healing your pets; you get one alignment point each time you heal them.

Chaotic characters gain one point of alignment each time they sleep with a foocubus, which is also a good way to gain experience.

With neutral characters, it is a bit more difficult. The easiest technique to get the first couple of points of alignment is to pray after the 300th turn with a minor trouble, since your initial prayer timeout is set to 300. This will only work for the first two points of alignment.

After that, you can get more alignment by giving gold to aligned priests. Giving a priest of your alignment (hope for a co-aligned Minetown altar) 600 times your level in gold will raise your alignment two points, but only if you don't have more than 2 times that amount of gold in your inventory at the time. So stash away all the gold you're not giving to the priest in a bag, then give to charity!

You can get a slightly better deal once you've bought the first 9 points of protection from that co-aligned priest. After that, if you spend 400 times your level in gold, you have only a small chance of getting more protection; you will usually get the alignment bonus instead (assuming the amount is more than half your current gold).

Sacrificing unicorns of other alignments is probably the next-easiest way to raise your alignment as a neutral character.

Neutral atheist non-Healer pacifists have an especially hard time raising their alignment. The only method available to them is to anger a cross-aligned priest. Ben Hiles has ascended an atheist pacifist Gnomish Wizard this way.

In 3.4.3 and earlier, a helm of opposite alignment could be used to open up other deities' methods of gaining alignment, such as casting healing spells on pets; unfortunately, as of 3.6.0, putting on or removing the helm resets your alignment to zero, making the practice pointless.

Engulfing monsters

Main article: Engulfing

If a monster engulfs you, applying a tooled horn will cause the monster to expel you. Pacifists should thus make it a priority to find a tooled horn. Other escape methods such as teleportation, ring of slow digestion, wand of slow monster, wand of opening, cloak of displacement, wand of digging, and the knock and slow monster spells can also be used in various situations. An engulfer without a digestion attack will eventually spit you out if you survive.[4][5]

Air elementals are dangerous opponents, since they are fast and often re-engulf you immediately after you escape. On a no-teleport level, zapping the air elemental with a wand of teleportation will move it out of your way. On levels that permit teleportation, you must zap yourself and not the air elemental in order to teleport outside of the monster.

Pets cannot be engulfed except by monsters with digestion attacks; however, a pet which is engulfed by a digestion attack suffers instadeath. Fortunately, the only monsters with digestion attacks are trappers, lurkers above, and purple worms. All three of them move slowly if at all, so they are easy to avoid if you have telepathy or (to a lesser extent) warning. Another option, if you don't intend to have any pet purple worms, is to genocide them.

Cockatrices

Most pets will not attack cockatrices. If you are unable to obtain a stoning-resistant pet such as a yellow dragon or a gargoyle, cockatrices will be very annoying obstacles. Taming, teleportation, genocide, conflict, and luring a wounded cockatrice into a pit are about the only ways to get rid of them without a pet that is willing to attack them. The easiest solution is to simply genocide them. In a normal game, genociding cockatrices is usually not a good idea, as their corpses are immensely useful against certain difficult enemies. This is not true in a pacifist game, as your pets will not wield cockatrice corpses if they have an artifact or no gloves, and the conduct keeps you from using it yourself. Additionally, any cockatrice corpses left on the ground could potentially be wielded against you by a soldier wearing gloves. The only potential uses for cockatrices in a pacifist game are with conflict, and deliberately stoning a weak pet golem to get a stronger stone golem.

High level monsters

A ring of conflict will cause your pets to attack other monsters (and you) regardless of any differences in monster level. If you don't have conflict, you will have to spend some effort to raise your pets' levels, since without conflict a pet will not attack monsters more than one level higher than it. Another option is to turn the monster into a green slime and either have a pet kill it or simply run away. It is possible to slime the Wizard of Yendor and polymorph into a nymph to steal the Book of the Dead. This has the added advantage of the Wizard not reappearing until after performing the invocation ritual.

A pet Archon will reach level 28 without any special effort. After that, the only way to raise its level is to give it potions of gain level. Of the monsters normally encountered in the game, only Asmodeus, Baalzebub, Orcus, the Wizard of Yendor, and the Riders are above level 29. It is usually best to bribe Asmodeus and Baalzebub, since otherwise they are fairly hard to kill. Asmodeus, in particular, is level 49, which is very difficult to handle without conflict. Orcus is level 30 and thus requires a level 29 Archon to kill—give your Archon one potion of gain level. The Riders have a base level of 30, but their actual level will be between 33 and 37, depending on your level and the depth of the Sanctum.

The Wizard of Yendor starts at level 30, but each death of the Wizard or his clones increases the level of his next appearance by one.[6] For this reason, it is a good idea to ensure that your Archon is several experience levels higher than the Wizard before beginning the ascension run, or have a level draining artifact on hand to use against him (check his level and hit points periodically with a stethoscope to make sure you don't kill him). As usual, if the level draining artifact is your quest artifact, be prepared as it will eventually be stolen by the Wizard if left out long enough. The most convenient source of potions of gain level is probably #looting the throne in Vlad's Tower repeatedly—about 2–4% of all monsters generated will carry such a potion.

Another option is to tame liches and grow them into arch-liches; a fully leveled arch-lich is level 37, sufficient to attack the Wizard for several incarnations. Arch-liches have the additional advantage of being covetous; once wounded both the Wizard and the tame lich will teleport to the upstairs (if it exists) and will continue to fight. Monsters will not escape upstairs or cast healing spells if you are not nearby, so the two will continue to fight until one of them dies—typically the Wizard, as an arch-lich has more damaging attacks. An arch-lich specifically wants the Book of the Dead and will therefore pick it up after the Wizard dies, but it may be difficult to get the Book back; the lich will still drop carried items due to being tame, but tends to immediately pick the Book up again.

Without a large supply of potions of gain level, it is always possible that the Wizard will reach a point where a pet Archon will refuse to attack him without conflict. The easiest way to get a level 49 pet is to tame a purple worm and farm for wraiths with the cursed Book of the Dead. Purple worms will gain a level whenever they swallow a wraith, ignoring corpse dropping odds. Beware the by-product arch-liches, and that the Wizard will haunt you unless you steal the book without killing him. Once at level 49, the pet worm will always be able to quickly kill the Wizard and will have enough HP to survive most combat. You still need to keep it away from disintegration blasts, polymorph traps, shapeshifters, and the Riders.

Traps

Certain traps are dangerous for pacifists. A polymorph trap can turn a strong pet into a weak pet. Level teleporters and trap doors can separate you from your pet. If you have a trap detection method, it might be a good idea to search each level for dangerous traps and disable them, or keep your pets away. In most cases, it is enough to put a cursed object or a boulder on the trap, or to dig a pit.

In the main dungeon, most traps can be avoided by walking in corridors instead of rooms. Digging your own corridors is a relatively safe method of travel, but tedious and usually not necessary. In Gehennom, try to stay in front of your pet at all times by using the layout of the maze to block your pet from walking in front of you. This will ensure that you encounter dangerous traps before your pet steps into them; once you find a dangerous trap, you should disable it immediately. Be aware, however, that when dangerous monsters are in the vicinity, you will want to keep your pet in front of you instead, so switch between the two modes of exploration as appropriate. Extrinsic telepathy is extremely valuable here, as is magic mapping.

Because you could lose your pet at any time to a trap, it is important for a pacifist to have at least two pets (if not more). A diversity of pets can handle a diversity of challenges.

Water and lava

Most pets, except for flying pets and a few that can survive under water, will die if you displace them into water or lava. If they die in this way, you will lose pacifist conduct. Be especially careful with pets on levels with water or lava. If you are not able to play with the necessary amount of caution, one alternative is to make sure all your pets can fly (and abandon the ones that can't).

In 3.6, if you drown a monster by creating a pool under it, either by digging a fountain or by doing the invocation, it breaks the conduct, so it is desirable to check for nearby monsters.

Monsters with special abilities

Many special abilities, such as mind flayers' brain-sucking attack and touch of death, won't work on your pet. Major exceptions include a cockatrice's stoning attack or a black dragon's breath attack, which can kill your pet instantly. Pets will not attack a footrice unless they are stoning resistant or you are causing conflict. The way to deal with cockatrices is to have a stoning resistant pet, teleport them, tame them, cancel them, or use genocide. Stoned pets may be recovered by the stone to flesh spell.

Black dragons are best handled by giving your pets reflection, or using cancellation or genocide.

A floating eye's gaze attack will affect pets. Keep any pets without reflection away from floating eyes until you obtain an expensive camera, wand of make invisible, or some other means of neutralizing their gaze attack. You can wake pets up with a leather drum, a tooled horn, or a depleted drum of earthquake or magical horn.

Medusa is another special case. If you reflect Medusa's gaze, you will lose pacifist conduct, so don't do that. Standard techniques for dispatching Medusa include using a pet with reflection, cancelling or blinding Medusa, or blindfolding yourself and dropping a wand of death in her path for her to use.

Wishing

Before wishing for an artifact, make sure that you can survive its artifact blast. Good artifact wishes for a pacifist include the following:

  • The Eye of the Aethiopica
    • Allows you to cast healing spells more frequently, if you are a Healer.
    • Telepathy helps you avoid hitting monsters.
    • Magic resistance is very helpful when polymorphing pets in polymorph traps.
    • Branchporting is useful for wraith luring.
  • The Orb of Fate
    • Confers half damage, which helps you survive.
    • The crystal ball function lets you look for dangerous traps. Recharge using the Platinum Yendorian Express Card for even greater effect.
    • Level teleport is handy for wraith luring.
  • The Platinum Yendorian Express Card
    • Pacifists rely on wands more than usual, especially wands of fire and lightning, which can engrave Elbereth, and wands of teleportation, which can move monsters out of the way. Being able to recharge wands is good.
    • Also confers telepathy and magic resistance.
    • Allows unlimited use of the Orb of Fate to search for traps. (A regular crystal ball will also work, but unless your intelligence is at least 20, a regular crystal ball has a chance of exploding when used.)
  • If you're not a Healer, a level draining artifact may be worth a wish.

Useful non-artifact wishes include the usual ascension kit equipment, plus any of the following depending on your situation:

  • blessed figurine of an Archon
  • blessed spellbook of charm monster
  • blessed magic whistle
  • blessed ring of conflict

No death drops

Pacifists get less loot, and what they do get is much less useful. Random items are generated only during initial level generation or as death drops which break the conduct. Monsters are created only with a very narrow selection of items. Polypiling, wishing, writing books and scrolls, divine gifts, and alchemy offer a way out, but all of these (except alchemy) break other conducts. On the flip side, you can identify items by that monsters were created with them, particularly when this varies by monster.

Pacifist ascensions

Pacifist Healers and Wizards are common, but a few other classes have been ascended as pacifists:

  • A pacifist Archeologist by Marvin
  • A pacifist Rogue by Marvin
  • A pacifist Monk (and 8 other conducts too) by Brad Sagarin

No YAPAPs have been posted to RGRN for a Barbarian, Caveman, Knight, Ranger, Priest, Samurai, Tourist, or Valkyrie.

On NAO, there have been 14 Healer, 12 Wizard, 3 Monk, 2 Tourist, and 1 each of Archaeologist, Barbarian, Caveman, Rogue, Priest, Knight, and Valkyrie ascensions.[7].

Pacifism is the most difficult conduct; only 0.8% of all winning NAO accounts have a pacifist ascension.[8]

Variants

All variants track Pacifist normally, but some have changes that make the conduct less frustrating and error-prone:

FIQHack

Weapon-tools always display "You begin bashing" when attacking unskilled with the tool; this helps the player realize their mistake if they accidentally attack with a pickaxe and it doesn't kill the monster.

XNetHack

If the player has not attacked any monsters after 100 turns have passed, they are prompted to confirm any melee attack. Once they confirm an attack, or kill a monster, the prompt no longer appears.
